channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: White House Announces New Sanctions to Block Iran’s Trading Activities
item.description: The Obama administration on Thursday announced an expanded list of Iranian companies and individuals that it said it would target to block their trading activities around the world.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: In Ukraine’s East, a Message for Protesters: Stop
item.description: In industrial eastern Ukraine, the base of support for President Viktor F. Yanukovich, the protest movement in Kiev is frowned upon, even derided.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: With the authorities gone from Independence Square in Kiev, protesters combined snow to build icy barricades less likely to be easily dismantled.

item.title: Bangladesh Executes Opposition Leader
item.description: Bangladesh on Thursday executed an opposition leader convicted of war crimes hours after the Supreme Court rejected his last-minute appeal, officials said. The death threatened to spark new violence ahead of national elections next month.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Interpreter at Mandela Memorial Says He Saw ‘Angels’
item.description: The man, accused by sign-language experts of being an impostor, said in interviews that he suffered from schizophrenia and had a tendency to violence.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH, JOHN ELIGON and ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: December 12
item.description: A temporary bridge being constructed over the Ganges River in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Laborers building a temporary bridge over the Ganges River in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, in preparation for the Magh Mela festival in January.

item.title: India Ink: For Gay Rights Advocates, Jubilation of Four Years Turns to Shock
item.description: The people who cheered a Delhi High Court ruling in 2009 that decriminalized homosexuality mourned the reversal of that landmark decision.
item.dc:creator: By VAIBHAV VATS
item.media:description: A gay rights activist at a demonstration in New Delhi on Thursday against the Supreme Court judgement to uphold a law criminalizing homosexuality.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Foreigner Faces Deportation Over Scooter Incident
item.description: A foreigner who apparently struck a pedestrian in Beijing with his scooter was first the subject of sympathy on the Chinese internet, then became a target of vitriol by millions, and now faces a fine and deportation. It was just the latest case of the whirlwind rush to judgment and a tendency to stake out extremes frequently seen in Chinese cyberspace.
item.dc:creator: By MIA LI
item.media:description: A series of photographs at first generated widespread sympathy for the foreigner before opinion shifted in favor of the woman he hit.

item.title: European Report Says Vatican Makes Progress in Policing Its Bank
item.description: Financial experts evaluated measures to combat money-laundering and concluded that a wide range of measures have been taken by the Holy See to remedy numerous deficiencies.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Familiar Ring to Retired Propaganda Chief’s Ode to an Ugly Bird
item.description: The Communist Party’s former propaganda chief has found a kind of post-retirement fame in a paean to an unsightly stork, although the lyrics appear to have been lifted from another song.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Li Changchun, at the Great Hall of the People in 2012.

item.title: Indian Court Removes Obstacle to Microsoft-Nokia Merger
item.description: The Delhi High Court ruled that Nokia would be allowed to transfer a phone factory to Microsoft, even though the plant was seized because of a tax dispute.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI

item.title: Letter From Europe: Recalling the Other Heroes of the Anti-Apartheid Struggle
item.description: The days of celebration of Nelson Mandela's life and the grief at his death have tempted some to limit the accolades to him while forgetting other contributions..
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oliver Tambo, center, with Nelson Mandela and Winnie Mandela at an African National Congress meeting in Soweto, South Africa, in 1990.

item.title: Lines Form Again in Pretoria for Last Glimpse of Mandela
item.description: The body of the former president is lying in state at the Union Buildings for the second of three days during which mourners may pay their last respects.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: People queued for buses heading to the government buildings in Pretoria where Nelson Mandela’s body was lying in state.

item.title: Hardships Linger for a Mending Ireland
item.description: A program of austerity, hailed as a successful recovery tool, has left many desperately struggling to survive.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Graffiti on a closed storefront in central Dublin reflects anger at the government and banks that many Irish feel after a crisis that almost caused a bankruptcy.

item.title: India Ink: After Muzaffarnagar Riots, a Standoff over Government Compensation
item.description: As winter’s chill sets in, those living in the Malakpur refugee camp insist they can’t leave without monetary relief, while the Uttar Pradesh government insists they can.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Gulbaar, right, with his brother Farmaan at a cemetery close to the Malakpur camp in Shamli district, Uttar Pradesh.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Huge Fines for Violators of One-Child Policy, but Little Accounting
item.description: Recent revelations about the huge amounts paid by families who violate China’s one-child policy have raised questions about just how the money is spent and spurred calls to ban the fines.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Elderly women carrying babies gather in a park in Beijing.

item.title: Hometown Remembers Madiba the Villager, Well Before Mandela the Icon
item.description: While the world admires Nelson Mandela as a freedom fighter, residents in his hometown, where he will be buried on Sunday, considered him just another villager.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN ELIGON
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kekana Geledwana, 92, in his home in Qunu, South Africa, with his daughter, Nombeko. Mr. Geledwana was friends with Nelson Mandela when he was president but was not afraid to challenge him, he said.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Big Change for China and the World
item.description: Is China, emboldened by its economic power, asserting itself in ways that mean the world is at an “inflection point,” as Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said in Beijing last week?
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: U.S. Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. meets with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the Great Hall of the People on Dec. 4.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Joining the $ and € ...
item.description: Russia’s Central Bank has adopted an official symbol for the national currency, the ruble, that was approved in a public vote.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Lawmaker’s Blood Rejected
item.description: The speaker of Israel’s Parliament ordered a blood-collection crew to leave the legislature’s premises on Wednesday after it turned down an offer of a blood donation from an Ethiopian-born lawmaker.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Leader Wins Confidence Vote
item.description: Prime Minister Enrico Letta of Italy won a confidence vote in the Senate, confirming his government’s majority after promising sweeping overhauls and urging lawmakers to back him or risk chaos.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Reprieve From Death
item.description: Lawyers for a leader of Bangladesh’s largest Islamic party sought Wednesday to have his death sentence thrown out after a late-night reprieve saved his life just hours before he was to be hanged.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Texas Plan to Execute Mexican May Harm U.S. Ties Abroad, Kerry Says
item.description: Edgar Arias Tamayo, 46, was convicted of shooting and killing a Houston police officer who was taking him to jail after a robbery in 1994.
item.dc:creator: By MANNY FERNANDEZ

item.title: Hagel Lifts Veil on Major Military Center in Qatar
item.description: The location of the operations center from which the Pentagon coordinated all missions in the Iraqi and Afghan wars was revealed when the defense secretary paid a very public visit.
item.category: Combined Air and Space Operations Center
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER

item.title: Police Question Parents in Baby’s Death
item.description: Officers were called to the Manhattan home of the baby’s parents twice before, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By J. DAVID GOODMAN

item.title: U.S. Colleges Finding Ideals Tested Abroad
item.description: Universities with programs in countries with autocratic governments are wrestling with how to respond to actions that fly in the face of democratic principles.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By TAMAR LEWIN
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prof. Xia Yeliang, an economist and professor at Peking University, was told to leave in October.
